DryingGear.title: How to dry your gear when it rains
DryingGear.subtitle: Practical advice from a local Tanzanian guide

cta.title: Your adventure awaits
cta.subtitle: Contact our experts to plan your Kilimanjaro ascent

methods.method1Title: Most reliable method: use body heat
methods.method1: When the sun is hidden, wind is low and no external heat source is available, the best way to dry clothes is to use your own body heat. Prepare wet garments by wringing them out as much as possible, put a dry layer next to your skin, then tuck the damp item under your jacket or fleece so your body heat slowly evaporates the moisture. This works especially well for small items such as gloves, socks and buffs.
methods.method2Title: Drying inside the tent: possible but not automatically effective
methods.method2: Suspending clothes inside a tent often fails because tents trap humid air and cause condensation. If you must dry inside, hang garments high, avoid touching the walls, and use vents to encourage airflow. When rain eases, open a small vent to create a slight cross-breeze.
methods.method3: Camp kitchens are warmer areas that can speed drying. Keep garments at a safe distance from flames (at least 1m) and turn them regularly. A perforated plastic bag can act as a mini-greenhouse to concentrate gentle heat around the fabric.
methods.method4: Pack a sealed dry-bag with a spare set of essential clothing (base layer, socks, t-shirt) that you never wear during the day. This 'insurance' kit lets you change into dry clothes after a long wet day and preserves core warmth at night.
methods.method5: Short pauses when rain eases or a gust of wind can be enough to dry small items. Stretch garments open to increase surface area and expose them to airflow â€” even ten minutes can significantly reduce dampness.
methods.mistakesTitle: Common mistakes and how to avoid them
methods.mistakes: Washing clothes on trek is often counterproductive in cold, humid mountain conditions. Laying garments on wet ground or pressing them against tent walls will slow drying and increase humidity problems. Walking in wet garments against skin increases heat loss and friction injuries.
methods.conclusionTitle: Conclusion: rain isn't the enemy, humidity is
methods.conclusion: With simple techniques â€” body heat, camp heat, wind and a dry-bag â€” you can manage moisture and stay comfortable on a wet trek. Anticipation and small habits make the difference between a miserable journey and an enjoyable adventure.
methods.tip: Guide tip: anticipate humidity to succeed on your Kilimanjaro trek

comment-maintenir-bonne-hygiene-kilimand.title: Maintaining good personal hygiene on Kilimanjaro
comment-maintenir-bonne-hygiene-kilimand.subtitle: Practical guide from a local Kilimanjaro guide

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro is an extraordinary adventure, but it takes place in conditions very different from daily life. One often overlooked topic is personal hygiene. With no showers, limited water and remote camps, many trekkers wonder how to stay clean for several days. Good hygiene on Kilimanjaro is essential to stay healthy and reach the summit. From my experience as a local guide, trekkers who follow basic hygiene routines complete the trek in better condition.

conditions.title: Conditions
conditions.content: Modern comforts don't exist on the mountain. Kilimanjaro is a protected natural area without hotel infrastructure. There are no showers on the mountain, whatever the route. Water is collected from rivers or natural springs and treated by the team. This water is prioritised for drinking, meal preparation and basic washing.

toilettes.title: Toilets
toilettes.content: Most camps provide basic public toilets supplied by the national park. These are simple cabins or temporary structures, sometimes without toilet paper or water for handwashing. Some teams provide private portable toilets, which are cleaner and more private â€” recommended for longer routes.

autonomie.title: Personal autonomy
autonomie.content: Camps are simple and hygiene relies on the trekker's personal autonomy. Biodegradable wipes, hand sanitizer, clean clothes and hygiene accessories are essential. A nightly routine â€” cleaning up each evening, changing clothes, foot care â€” helps conserve energy and avoid health issues.

mental.title: Mental preparation
mental.content: Discipline throughout the trek is crucial. Mental preparation helps accept constraints, reduce stress and support better acclimatisation. Planning equipment and habits transforms the experience into a positive adventure.

toilettes-privees-necessaires.title: Are private toilets necessary for a Kilimanjaro ascent?
toilettes-privees-necessaires.subtitle: Local guide advice

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Most camps provide basic public toilets supplied by the national park. These are simple, shared facilities that can be poorly maintained during high season. Toilet paper is not always provided, and water for handwashing may be lacking.

public.title: Public toilets
public.content: These facilities meet basic needs but do not offer modern comfort. Prepare by bringing personal supplies (paper, sanitizer, wipes).

private.title: Private toilets
private.content: Private portable toilets offer greater cleanliness, privacy and lower health risk. They are cleaned regularly and recommended on longer routes.

recommandation.title: Recommendation
recommandation.content: For multi-day ascents, especially on Lemosho or long circuits, plan for at least one private toilet per camp to improve group comfort and health.

articles-hygiene-emporter.title: Which hygiene items to pack for a Kilimanjaro trek?
articles-hygiene-emporter.subtitle: Local guide advice

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Hygiene on Kilimanjaro is a real challenge: no showers, basic toilets, cold temperatures and limited water. Packing the right items is essential to stay clean and healthy.

corporelle.title: Personal hygiene
corporelle.content: Biodegradable wipes for body, soap or antibacterial gel, solid deodorant, moisturiser and lip balm are essential even without showers.

pieds.title: Foot care
pieds.content: Clean breathable hiking socks, anti-friction balm and small dressings or adhesive strips help prevent blisters and infections.

toilettes.title: Toilet hygiene
toilettes.content: Biodegradable toilet paper, waste bags to pack out used items, hand sanitizer and wet wipes for quick cleaning when water is scarce.

autres.title: Other essentials
autres.content: Compact microfiber towel, small first-aid kit and travel toothbrush/toothpaste.

rester-propre-sans-eau.title: How to stay clean without water on Kilimanjaro?
rester-propre-sans-eau.subtitle: Local guide advice

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Camps are rustic, there are no showers and water is prioritised for drinking and cooking. Still, hygiene is possible with the right kit and techniques.

importance.title: Why it matters
importance.content: Preventing infections and digestive issues, protecting skin and feet, and maintaining morale are vital reasons to keep basic hygiene even without water.

pratique.title: Practical tips
pratique.content: Use biodegradable wet wipes, hand sanitizer, keep a clean set of dry clothes for the evening and care for your feet.

soins-pieds.title: Foot care
soins-pieds.content: Clean and dry feet, apply protective balms and rotate socks to prevent blisters and infections.

hygiene-femmes-ascension.title: Hygiene advice for women during the ascent
hygiene-femmes-ascension.subtitle: Practical guidance from a local guide

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Climbing Kilimanjaro presents specific hygiene challenges for women: rustic camps, limited water and basic toilet facilities. Preparing a complete hygiene kit and knowing how to manage needs makes the trek more comfortable and safer.

kit.title: Hygiene kit
kit.content: Bring biodegradable pads or tampons, intimate wipes, hand sanitizer, sealable bags for used items, moisturiser and lip balm.

toilets.title: Toilets
toilets.content: Sanitary facilities are limited. Private portable toilets provide more privacy and cleanliness and are recommended on longer routes.

periods.title: Managing periods
periods.content: Bring enough menstrual supplies, cleaning options (wipes, sanitizer) and backup solutions (menstrual cup + alternatives) for the entire trek.

cycle.title: Menstrual cycle
cycle.content: Altitude and stress can slightly alter the menstrual cycle. Pack extra supplies even if your period is not expected.

hygiene-alimentaire.title: Food hygiene during the ascent of Kilimanjaro
hygiene-alimentaire.subtitle: Practical guidance from a local guide for a safe, healthy trek

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Climbing Kilimanjaro is demanding. Food hygiene is crucial to avoid foodborne illness, stomach problems and fatigue. Good food hygiene helps maintain energy throughout the ascent.

preparation.title: Meal preparation
preparation.content: Cooks filter or boil all water used for cooking and drinking. Prep surfaces are cleaned and perishables stored safely to limit bacterial growth.

conseils.title: Practical tips
conseils.content: Wash hands with soap or sanitizer before meals, avoid raw or undercooked foods, prefer hot meals and do not share plates or cutlery.

eau-logistique.title: Water & logistics
eau-logistique.content: Each camp has separate areas for cooking and eating. Potable water is available but personal filtration/treatment is recommended. Stay hydrated to prevent altitude illness and protect digestive health.

preparer-son-corps-altitude-kilimandjaro.title: How to prepare your body for Kilimanjaro's altitude
preparer-son-corps-altitude-kilimandjaro.subtitle: Advice to prepare for altitude and improve your summit chances.

overview.title: How to prepare your body for Kilimanjaro's altitude
overview.content:
Altitude is the main challenge when climbing Kilimanjaro and the biggest factor affecting summit success. From around 3,000 meters, the amount of oxygen in the air decreases gradually. The body must adapt to this lower oxygen level to continue functioning normally.

Unlike physical fitness, altitude cannot be "trained" in a gym. A very fit person can still struggle at altitude. Success on Kilimanjaro therefore depends on good acclimatization, a suitable pace, strict hydration, and responsible behaviour in the mountains.

As a local guide I see each season that people who respect the altitude have far greater chances of reaching the summit than those who underestimate it.

how-body-reacts.title: How the body reacts to altitude
how-body-reacts.content:
At altitude, the body receives less oxygen with each breath. To compensate, the heart rate increases and breathing becomes faster. This is a natural and normal reaction, but it takes time for the body to adapt.

If you ascend too quickly, the body does not have time to adapt properly. This can cause symptoms like headaches, nausea, severe fatigue, loss of appetite or sleep disturbances. These signs indicate the body is struggling with altitude.

Preparation therefore starts with a fundamental rule: ascending slowly is not a choiceâ€”it's a necessity.

slow-pace.title: Adopt a slow, steady pace
slow-pace.content:
On Kilimanjaro one rule applies to everyone without exception: "pole pole", which means to walk slowly. This pace conserves energy and improves oxygenation of the muscles and brain.

Even very fit people must accept this slowness. Altitude makes no distinction between an athlete and a beginner. Walking too fast increases the risk of acute mountain sickness and reduces recovery capacity.

A slow, steady pace maintained day after day is one of the most effective factors for safely reaching the summit.

choose-itinerary.title: Choose an itinerary that aids acclimatization
choose-itinerary.content:
Preparing for altitude starts before you set foot on the mountain. The choice of itinerary is essential. Some Kilimanjaro routes offer a more gradual ascent and include acclimatization days or climbs, helping the body adapt more effectively.

Spending more nights at altitude helps the body produce more red blood cells, improving oxygen transport in the blood. A good local guide adapts the itinerary to the group's level, pace, and reactions.

hydrate-eat.title: Stay hydrated and eat well
hydrate-eat.content:
At altitude the body dehydrates faster, even when thirst is low. Drinking regularly throughout the day is essential to support acclimatization and limit negative effects of altitude.

A balanced diet rich in carbohydrates provides the energy needed for the effort and helps the body manage reduced oxygen. Eating enough, even without appetite, is an integral part of altitude preparation.

listen-guide.title: Listen to your body and communicate with the guide
listen-guide.content:
Everyone reacts differently to altitude. Some adapt quickly, others need more time. It's therefore essential to listen to your body's signals and inform the guide as soon as unusual symptoms appear.

Quick communication allows pace adjustments, preventive measures and, if necessary, avoids more serious complications. An experienced local guide monitors the group's health daily and acts before situations worsen.

guide-tip.title: Guide tip ðŸ”ï¸
guide-tip.content: On Kilimanjaro, altitude is not to be challenged. Those who respect it, walk slowly and listen to their body, reach higher and more calmly.

engager-guide-local-kilimandjaro.title: Why hiring a local guide is essential for Kilimanjaro
engager-guide-local-kilimandjaro.subtitle: The guide's role, safety and local benefits

overview.title: Why hiring a local guide is essential for Kilimanjaro
overview.content: A local guide is more than a pathfinder: they protect, advise and ensure safety.

role-guide.title: The guideâ€™s daily role
role-guide.content: The guide accompanies the group, monitors health and adapts the pace.

safety.title: Safety first
safety.content: They make decisions to slow the pace, add acclimatization days or descend when needed.

logistics.title: Logistics and comfort management
logistics.content: They organise gear, food and supervise porters to keep the group comfortable.

morale.title: Moral support and motivation
morale.content: Guides provide encouragement and help maintain motivation during hard moments.

culture.title: Cultural and environmental discovery
culture.content: They share knowledge about local flora, fauna, history and traditions.

economy.title: Support to the local economy
economy.content: Hiring guides supports local livelihoods and sustainable employment.

mam-role.title: Guideâ€™s role regarding acute mountain sickness
mam-role.content: Guides spot early MAM signs and act quickly with appropriate measures.

choix-itineraire-preparation-kilimandjar.title: How route choice is part of Kilimanjaro preparation
choix-itineraire-preparation-kilimandjar.subtitle: Choose the right route to improve acclimatization

overview.title: How route choice is part of Kilimanjaro preparation
overview.content: Route choice affects acclimatization, difficulty and daily comfort. Progressive routes increase summit chances.

route-role.title: Route role in pace and acclimatization
route-role.content: Some routes offer a gentler ascent and more nights at altitude, promoting red blood cell production.

ascent-rate.title: Ascent rate and nights at altitude
ascent-rate.content: Lemosho starts slowly with acclimatization days; other routes ascend more directly.

difficulty.title: Difficulty varies by route
difficulty.content: Machame is demanding; Lemosho is more gradual; Rongai is steadierâ€”pick by ability.

daily-comfort.title: Daily comfort depends on route
daily-comfort.content: Route affects campsite crowding and psychological comfort.

weather.title: Route impact on weather and terrain
weather.content: Routes cross different climate zones; Rongai tends to be drier and may suit wet seasons.

success-rate.title: Route choice affects summit success
success-rate.content: Longer, progressive routes tend to have higher summit success rates.

guide-role.title: Guideâ€™s key role
guide-role.content: An experienced guide recommends the best route based on age, fitness and season.

choisir-chaussures-randonnee-kilimandjar.title: How to choose hiking boots for Kilimanjaro
choisir-chaussures-randonnee-kilimandjar.subtitle: Gear advice from a local guide

overview.title: Overview
overview.content: Choosing the right hiking boots for Kilimanjaro is essential. The mountain covers many climates and terrains. Poorly chosen boots can cause pain, blisters or injury and jeopardise summit success. Well-chosen boots provide comfort, stability and protection. As a local guide, I often see poorly chosen footwear cause unnecessary suffering or abandonment during climbs.

terrain.title: Adapt shoes for Kilimanjaroâ€™s varied terrain
terrain.content: Kilimanjaro is not a simple walk. Trails pass through humid forest, dry volcanic slopes, rocky scree and cold near-summit zones. Boots must provide grip, protection and stability. Soles need reliable traction for muddy, slippery or dusty conditions depending on the season.

high-cut.title: Why high-cut hiking boots
high-cut.content: High-cut boots are strongly recommended for Kilimanjaro. They support the ankle, reducing sprain risk, notably on long descents. Ankle support becomes crucial as fatigue sets in and terrain becomes uneven. High-cut boots also offer better protection from cold and rubbing.

comfort.title: Comfort first
comfort.content: On Kilimanjaro the priority is endurance, not speed. Boots must be comfortable for long walking days, often over six hours. Choose boots that fit your foot shape and provide toe-box space â€” feet swell with exertion and altitude. Tight boots cause blisters, black toenails and worsening pain day after day.

sole.title: Importance of the sole
sole.content: The sole is key for Kilimanjaro boots. It should be stiff enough to protect the foot from rocks and volcanic terrain while remaining comfortable for long walks. Good shock absorption reduces muscle fatigue and protects knees during long descents. Excellent traction is essential for wet or unstable ground.

waterproof.title: Waterproof yet breathable
waterproof.content: Weather on Kilimanjaro changes fast. In the forest rain and humidity are frequent, while high altitudes are cold. Waterproof boots keep feet dry and prevent blisters and infections but must be breathable to avoid sweat buildup during exertion. Balance waterproofing with breathability for lasting comfort.

test-shoes.title: Break in your boots before the trek
test-shoes.content: Starting a trek in new boots is a common mistake. Boots for Kilimanjaro should be tested and broken in several weeks before departure. Wear them on long hikes with your pack to ensure no rubbing or pain. Well-broken-in boots greatly reduce injury risk during the climb.

season.title: Match shoes to season and route
season.content: Season and chosen route strongly influence the type of boots required. In cold season or near-summit climbs insulation matters. Some routes are longer or more technical and need more robust boots. A local guide can advise the best model for the conditions.

DressForZones.title: How to dress for the 5 climate zones of Kilimanjaro
DressForZones.subtitle: Local guide clothing advice, zone by zone

sections.intro: Climbing Kilimanjaro isn't just about changing altitude: you pass through five distinct natural zones, each with its own climate, benefits and hazards. At the foot of the mountain you'll walk through hot, humid rainforest.
sections.intro2: A few days later you'll be in an almost arctic environment where night temperatures can drop to â€“20Â°C. This fast transition makes clothing choices essential for your safety, comfort and performance.
sections.blockquote: Kilimanjaro doesn't ask you to be the strongest â€” it asks you to be the best prepared. Clothing is your first line of defence.
sections.zone1: Climate: hot, humid and sometimes heavy â€” showers can occur even in the dry season. Goal: stay dry, avoid sweating, and protect against insects and vegetation.
sections.zone1_2: Long-sleeve technical t-shirt (no cotton), lightweight trekking trousers, a hat or cap and well-ventilated but sturdy shoes are essential to stay comfortable and avoid setting off wet from the start.
sections.zone2: Climate: cooler, drier, and wind starts to pick up. Goal: retain warmth without overheating.
sections.zone2_2: Choose a synthetic technical t-shirt, keep a light fleece or softshell to hand, regular trekking trousers and a buff to protect from wind and dust.
sections.zone3: Climate: cold and dry, strong winds, intense solar radiation. Goal: protect from sun by day and cold in shade.
sections.zone3_2: Fleece plus windproof layer, lined trousers or over-trousers, light gloves, high-altitude sunglasses and a sun hat (or buff+cap combo) make the ideal kit.
sections.zone4: Climate: very cold, biting winds, dry air. Goal: conserve heat â€” every calorie counts.
sections.zone4_2: Thermal base layers (top+bottom), a warm fleece, a lightweight down jacket, insulating over-trousers, warm gloves with liners and a beanie covering the ears are critical here.
sections.zone5Title: Zone 5: Summit â€“ Arctic Zone (5,500 â€“ 5,895 m)
sections.zone5: Climate: temperatures down to â€“20Â°C, fierce winds and a freezing night. Goal: keep heat while moving and face the night wind.
sections.zone5_2: Thermal underwear, a warm fleece plus heavy down jacket, waterproof windproof hardshell, insulated trousers, insulated mitts with liners, beanie + buff, merino socks reserved for summit push and a headlamp are indispensable for the night ascent and summit.
sections.advice: At the summit, cold and wind can sap your strength. Dress before you feel cold, put on your goggles as soon as the sun rises, and move step by step. Clothing preparation is as much part of the summit as the walk itself.

hero.title: Authentic Kilimanjaro Experience: Materuni & Chemka (2 Days)
hero.description: Dive into rural Tanzania: Chagga culture, coffee workshop and relaxation at Chemka hot springs.

overview.title: Overview
overview.intro: A perfect 2-day program combining culture, an easy hike and relaxation in a natural oasis.

day1.title: Day 1: Authentic Chagga Cultural Immersion, Coffee & Materuni Waterfall
day1.subtitle: Village of Materuni
day1.description:
Your journey to the falls involves an easy to moderate guided walk through Arabica coffee plantations and local Chagga villages. This hike offers an authentic and intimate insight into local culture and daily life on the slopes of Kilimanjaro.

The 80-meter waterfall is spectacular. You can enjoy a refreshing and invigorating dip in the crystal-clear, cold water at the base of the falls, fed by the eternal snows.

After visiting the waterfall, you will participate in an interactive coffee-making workshop. You will discover and participate in the complete process of preparing the famous Tanzanian coffee, from bean to cup.

You will walk through Chagga villages, where you can interact directly with locals, discover their traditions, and experience the warmth of local hospitality.

day2.title: Day 2: Ultimate Relaxation at Kikuletwa (Chemka) Hot Springs
day2.subtitle: Kikuletwa (Chemka) Hot Springs
day2.description:
The bright blue and turquoise color of the hot spring is absolutely fascinating, contrasting with the surrounding landscape.

The water maintains a constant warm temperature year-round, making it perfect for deeply relaxing swimming.

The hot spring is set amid thick greenery and majestic trees, creating a serene, secluded atmosphere ideal for relaxing in nature. It is a true oasis of the savanna.

Spend time floating and swimming in the clear, warm water â€“ a moment of pure escape and rejuvenation.

inclusions.title: Price Includes
inclusions.items: 1) All road transfers required for the 2-day itinerary (transfers to/from your lodging in the Moshi area and site transfers)|||2) French-speaking guide for 2 days + local guides for specific activities|||3) All entrance & conservation fees for Materuni waterfall, the coffee workshop and Kikuletwa (Chemka) hot springs|||4) Coffee workshop|||5) Two lunches (Day 1 in Materuni village and Day 2 at Chemka) and bottled water provided throughout the tour

hero.title: Total Escape: Culture, Adventure & Flavours of Zanzibar (8 Days)
hero.description:
The best of the Spice Island in full immersion.

This isnâ€™t a simple beach stay â€” itâ€™s an intense dive into the heart of the Indian Ocean. Over eight days youâ€™ll experience Zanzibarâ€™s striking contrasts: from Mnembaâ€™s turquoise reefs to the authentic flavours of Darajani Market and the vibrant history of Stone Townâ€™s alleys. Prepare for a complete adventure led by a local guide.

day1.title: Day 1: Arrival in Zanzibar
day1.description: On this day you will arrive at Zanzibar International Airport (ZNZ) or the ferry port. Upon arrival you will meet our driver just outside arrivals. The driver will display your name on a sign (example: "RAMA WAHABU"). Pickup depends on your flight or ferry details. You will provide details when confirming the package. No extra charge for the transfer.

day2.title: Day 2: Full-Day Safari Blue Trip
day2.description: A full day of sailing around the mangroves and snorkeling along Menai Bay, one of Zanzibarâ€™s best coral reefs. Sail to Kwale Island, relax on a sandbank, swim and snorkel. Enjoy a fresh seafood barbecue: octopus, lobster, squid, fish, etc. Taste exotic fresh fruits such as banana, watermelon, pineapple and mangoes. Return to the hotel after a day full of adventure.

day3.title: Day 3: Market Experience & Traditional Cooking
day3.description: Start your day exploring Zanzibarâ€™s cuisine by meeting your guide at Darajani Market to choose fresh ingredients. Youâ€™ll gain a deeper insight into the islandâ€™s food, people and culture through a hands-on cooking class and local market visit â€” designed for food lovers to learn beyond a restaurant experience.

day4.title: Day 4: Mnemba Dolphins & Snorkeling
day4.description: Head out to observe and swim with dolphins, then explore Mnemba Islandâ€™s colourful reefs on this day trip. Boats depart daily from Muyuni Beach, Matemwe. Enjoy abundant tropical fish and marine life at one of Zanzibarâ€™s top snorkeling spots. Fresh tropical fruits are served on board and you can photograph the beautiful sandbank near Mnemba (only at low tide). After the excursion enjoy a seafood lunch at Muyuni Beach before returning to your hotel.

day5.title: Day 5: Blue Lagoon & The Rock Restaurant
day5.description: Explore tropical beauty and snorkel at Michamviâ€™s Blue Lagoon among colourful fish and starfish. Afterwards, dine and photograph the unique The Rock Restaurant. Return to your hotel to rest after the visit.

day6.title: Day 6: Spice Farm & Stone Town Tour
day6.description: Taste and smell spices grown and used in Zanzibari cuisine: cardamom, cinnamon, black pepper, cloves, etc. Enjoy a locally prepared spiced rice lunch with fresh fried fish and fruit. Learn Zanzibarâ€™s history and culture with a professional local guide in Stone Town visiting the House of Wonders, Freddie Mercuryâ€™s House, the Old Slave Market and the Sultanâ€™s Palace. Take photos and shop for souvenirs in Stone Townâ€™s streets.

day7.title: Day 7: Prison Island with Nakupenda Sandbank
day7.description: Your driver will pick you up after breakfast for a full-day boat trip to Prison Island and Nakupenda sandbank near Stone Town. Observe and photograph Aldabra giant tortoises on Prison Island and learn the islandâ€™s short history. Relax, swim and snorkel at Nakupenda sandbank and enjoy a fresh seafood barbecue and tropical fruit tasting. Return to your hotel after the excursion.

day8.title: Day 8: Transfer to the Airport â€” Farewell!
day8.description: Our driver will pick you up at the agreed time and transfer you to the airport (ZNZ) or ferry port according to your departure schedule.

hero.title: The Senses Archipelago: Diving & Culture in Zanzibar (5 Days)
hero.description: The best of the Spice Island in express format. This is not a simple beach stay; it's an intense immersion in the beating heart of the Indian Ocean. In just five days, you'll experience the striking contrast of Zanzibar: from the turquoise brilliance of Mnemba's underwater world and the Safari Blue to the vibrant authenticity of Stone Town's labyrinthine streets.

day1.title: Day 1: Transfer to Hotel
day1.description: You will arrive at Zanzibar International Airport. Upon arrival, you will meet our driver just outside arrivals. The driver will display your name on a sign. Pick-up timing will depend on your flight details, which you'll provide when confirming your package. No additional charges for airport transfer to your hotel.

day2.title: Day 2: Full Day Safari Blue Trip
day2.description: A full day of sailing around mangroves and snorkeling along Menai Bay, one of Zanzibar's best coral reefs. Sail to Kwale Island, relax on a sandbank, swim and snorkel. Enjoy the best fresh seafood barbecue: octopus, lobster, squid, fish, etc. Taste exotic fresh fruits such as bananas, watermelon, pineapple, and mangoes.

day3.title: Day 3: Half-Day - Mnemba Dolphins & Snorkeling
day3.description: Swim with dolphins and capture incredible photos. Snorkel and observe a variety of colorful tropical fish, corals and other marine creatures. Explore the coral reefs and marine life around Mnemba Island. This half-day will take you to the other part of Zanzibar's northern coast, Matemwe.

day4.title: Day 4: Stone Town, Spice Farm & Prison Island
day4.description: Explore while tasting and smelling different spices cultivated and used in Zanzibar cuisine; cardamom, cinnamon, black pepper, cloves, etc. Learn the history and culture of the Zanzibar people with a professional local tour guide in Stone Town, visiting the most iconic sites. Enjoy a delicious lunch of locally-prepared spiced rice at the farm with fresh fish and fruits such as bananas, mangoes, pineapples, etc. View and photograph giant Aldabra tortoises on Prison Island and discover its brief history.

day5.title: Day 5: Transfer to Airport, Farewell!
day5.description: After five days of vacation in Zanzibar, you will take your return flight. Your driver will take you to the airport according to your flight schedule. Kwaheri!

serengeti.name: Safari Bivouac 8 Days: The Wild Call of Northern Tanzania
serengeti.description:
Forget the everyday. This is not just a trip, it's a total immersion. For 8 days, you will live at the rhythm of the heart of Africa, where luxury is measured by the vastness of the sky and the authenticity of the moment.

This safari is tailored for the adventurer within you. By choosing bivouac (camping), you don't just observe nature, you sleep in it. Listen to the distant roar of a lion in the Serengeti, feel the ground vibrate at the passage of Tarangire's elephants, and let yourself be lulled by the night song of the savanna.

kilimanjaro.name: The Machame Route (7 Days Trek): The Scenic Ascent
kilimanjaro.description: Often called the "Whisky Route", the Machame route is Kilimanjaro's most popular itinerary, and for good reason. It offers spectacular and varied scenery, traversing five distinct climate zones. This 7-day mountain itinerary is highly recommended. It includes a shorter acclimatization day between Barranco Camp and Karanga Camp, which is crucial for adapting to altitude and significantly increases your chances of reaching the summit safely.

itineraries.description: We offer five of the seven routes up Kilimanjaro â€“ the best and safest ones! These routes range from five to eleven days, but our itineraries include a night at a local lodge on either side of the climb.

marangu.title: Conquer the Roof of Africa: Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro via the Marangu Route in 5 Days

lemosho.title: Lemosho Route
lemosho.description: The Lemosho is one of our favourite routes up Kilimanjaro as it has varied and beautiful scenery. It also has a high summit success rate!

rongai.title: Rongai Route
rongai.description: The Rongai is a quiet and pretty route that lets you see both sides of the mountain. There are no steep sections, rather it's a gradual climb.

northernCircuit.title: Northern Circuit
northernCircuit.description: The Northern Circuit (also known as the Grand Traverse) is the newest route up Kilimanjaro and it has an excellent summit success rate.

machame.title: The Machame Route (7 Days Trek): The Scenic Ascent
machame.description: Often called the "Whisky Route", the Machame route is Kilimanjaro's most popular itinerary, and for good reason. It offers spectacular and varied scenery, traversing five distinct climate zones.

umbwe.title: Umbwe Route
umbwe.description: The Umbwe Route is the most challenging and least used path up Kilimanjaro. It's a steep and direct ascent that offers incredible views but requires excellent physical fitness.

tripDetails.title: Climb Kilimanjaro

countryInfo.title: Country info and facts
countryInfo.description: Here are the basics you need to know about Tanzania to help you prepare for your adventure, like the nearest airport to Mt Kilimanjaro and the local currency. We also discuss the seasons and potential health risks for climbing Africa's tallest mountain!

airports.title: Airports
airports.content: The nearest airport and the one all our clients use is Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO) just outside the city of Arusha. When coming from outside of East Africa, you must usually fly via Nairobi (Kenya) or Dar es Salaam (Tanzania) to catch a connecting flight to JRO.

seasons.title: Seasons
seasons.learnMore: To learn more, please read Best time to climb Kilimanjaro.

visa.title: Visa and Immigration
visa.content: A standard Tanzanian tourist visa is valid for up to 90 days and costs US$50. US citizens must purchase a multiple-entry visa for $100 that is valid for a year. Note, however, that a visa isn't required for nationals from around 50 countries worldwide, including South Africa, Kenya, Hong Kong, Singapore, China, India, Brazil and Turkey. Learn more here.

health.title: Health and Safety
health.content: It's safe to climb Kilimanjaro when you travel with a reputable tour operator who has your health and safety as their number one priority. The biggest safety issue on a Kilimanjaro climb is the extreme altitude (please read Kilimanjaro altitude sickness so you understand the situation). Note that you must have travel insurance that covers you for hiking up to 6,000 m above sea level to be allowed to climb Kilimanjaro with Latanzanieaucourdelanature. A good all-round article to read is Kilimanjaro safety.

faqs.q2: Where do I sleep on Mount Kilimanjaro?

faqs.title: FAQs
faqs.question2: Where do I sleep on Mount Kilimanjaro?
faqs.question3: When is the best time to climb Mount Kilimanjaro?
faqs.answer1: Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro is safe when you travel with a reputable tour operator like Latanzanieaucourdelanature. We prioritize your health and safety with experienced guides, proper equipment, and well-planned itineraries that allow for proper acclimatization. Our success rate is over 90% for climbers who follow our guidance.
faqs.answer2: On Mount Kilimanjaro, you'll sleep in tents at designated campsites. Each campsite has basic facilities including toilets and dining areas. Our camping equipment is high-quality and designed for the mountain conditions. On some routes like Marangu, you'll sleep in huts with bunk beds instead of tents.
faqs.answer3: The best times to climb Mount Kilimanjaro are during the dry seasons: January to March and June to October. During these periods, you'll experience clearer skies, less rain, and better visibility. The weather can be unpredictable on the mountain, so proper gear is essential regardless of when you climb.

hero.subtitle: Discovering the natural wonders of Tanzania through authentic experiences

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.paragraph1: At Latanzanieaucourdelanature, we believe that travel should be transformative. Our mission is to connect travelers with Tanzania's most spectacular landscapes while supporting local communities and preserving the natural environment for future generations.
mission.paragraph2: We are committed to responsible tourism that respects both wildlife and local cultures, ensuring that each journey contributes positively to the places and people we visit.

story.title: Our Journey

2010.title: The Beginning
2010.description: Founded by passionate local Tanzanian guides who wanted to share their incredible homeland's natural beauty with the world.

2015.title: International Recognition
2015.description: Recognized by National Geographic as one of East Africa's leading sustainable tour operators for our conservation efforts.

2020.title: Community Partnership
2020.description: Expanded our programs to include community tourism initiatives, directly benefiting local villages near our destinations.

2025.title: Looking Forward
2025.description: Continue to innovate in sustainable tourism while expanding our offerings to include new destinations and experiences across Tanzania.

heritage.title: A Summit Heritage
heritage.paragraph1: The idea of La Tanzanie au cÅ“ur de la nature is based on a deep, generational respect for the mountain and its nature.
heritage.paragraph2: My journey began in the footsteps of my father, a devoted and resilient porter who served the climbing community for more than two decades, walking the trails until the age of 42. His strength, his experience and his intimate knowledge of every ridge and every path became the blueprint for my own life.
heritage.paragraph3: I grew up immersed in mountain culture, inspired by his commitment. I followed his path, mastering the trails from a young age to become a certified Local Guide.
heritage.paragraph4: Today, I lead treks and safaris with the wisdom and passion passed down by my family. La Tanzanie au cÅ“ur de la nature is more than just a tour operator; it is the culmination of a life lived on these slopes, honoring the legacy of the true mountain heroes. We are a family of local guides committed to offering you an authentic, safe and deeply meaningful adventure.

story.imageCatchphrase: Where community, culture and conservation meet

engagement.title: Community Engagement
engagement.paragraph1: We support community-led conservation and livelihood projects that deliver long-term benefits.
engagement.paragraph2: Our partnerships fund education, healthcare and environmental programs in the communities where we operate.
engagement.paragraph3: We work closely with local leaders to design tours that respect cultural protocols and promote sustainable income.
engagement.paragraph4: Each booking contributes to small-scale development initiatives that are overseen by community partners.

hero.description: Often called the "Whisky Route", the Machame route is Kilimanjaro's most popular itinerary, and for good reason. It offers spectacular and varied scenery, traversing five distinct climate zones. This 7-day mountain itinerary is highly recommended. It includes a shorter acclimatization day between Barranco Camp and Karanga Camp, which is crucial for adapting to altitude and significantly increases your chances of reaching the summit safely.

day0.title: Arrival Day: Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO) â†’ Moshi or Arusha
day0.description:
Upon arrival at Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO), a member of our team will welcome you and drive you to your hotel in Moshi or Arusha. This transfer will allow you to relax and recover from your flight.

In the evening, your head guide will come to your hotel for a comprehensive briefing about the climb. They will examine your equipment piece by piece to ensure you have everything you need, answer all your questions, and mentally prepare you for the adventure ahead.

day1.title: Trek Day 1: Machame Gate (1,800 m) â†’ Machame Camp (2,835 m)
day1.description: After breakfast, we drive to Machame Gate (about 1 hour from Moshi). Once registration formalities are completed, you'll bid farewell to civilization and begin your ascent. The first day is a steady climb through magnificent, dense rainforest. The trail is well-maintained but can be muddy and slippery. Along the way, keep your eyes open to spot black and white Colobus monkeys. You'll arrive at Machame Camp in the late afternoon, where your tents will already be set up.

day2.title: Trek Day 2: Machame Camp (2,835 m) â†’ Shira Camp (3,850 m)
day2.description: You'll leave the rainforest and enter the moorland zone. The trail becomes steeper and the landscape opens up, offering magnificent views of the plains below. The vegetation changes dramatically, with giant heathers and senecios. Today's stage is shorter, which helps with acclimatization. You'll cross a small valley before climbing onto the Shira Plateau, where you'll reach Shira 2 Camp. In clear weather, the summit of Kibo and Mount Meru to the west are visible.

day3.title: Trek Day 3: Shira Camp (3,850 m) â†’ Lava Tower (4,600 m) â†’ Barranco Camp (3,900 m)
day3.description: Today is crucial for acclimatization: "Climb high, sleep low". You'll ascend to Lava Tower (4,600 m), where you'll have lunch. You might start to feel the effects of altitude, but this is perfectly normal. After lunch, you'll descend into the magnificent Barranco Valley (3,900 m), where you'll spend the night. This descent helps your body tremendously to adapt to altitude. Barranco Camp is spectacular, nestled beneath the imposing Barranco Wall and surrounded by giant senecios.

day4.title: Trek Day 4: Barranco Camp (3,900 m) â†’ Karanga Camp (3,995 m)
day4.description:
This is the day that distinguishes the 7-day itinerary from the 6-day one. It begins with the day's most exciting challenge: the Barranco Wall. This is not technical climbing, but rather "easy scrambling" where you'll need to use your hands and feet to climb the 250-meter wall. Your guides will be there to ensure a safe and fun progression.

Once at the top, you'll be rewarded with stunning views. The rest of the day is a series of ascents and descents through alpine valleys to Karanga Camp. This short day is essential for strengthening your acclimatization before the final climb to base camp.

day5.title: Trek Day 5: Karanga Camp (3,995 m) â†’ Barafu Camp (4,673 m)
day5.description:
Another day of short, steady walking to preserve your energy. You'll traverse arid, rocky landscape, joining the junction with the Mweka route. The climb to Barafu Camp ("ice" in Swahili) is constant. The camp is situated on an exposed, windy ridge, offering spectacular views of the peaks of Kibo and Mawenzi.

You'll arrive at camp for lunch, leaving you the entire afternoon to rest, prepare your summit equipment, eat an early dinner (around 5:30 PM), and try to sleep as much as possible. The excitement and nervousness are building!

day6.title: Trek Day 6: SUMMIT DAY - Barafu (4,673 m) â†’ Uhuru Peak (5,895 m) â†’ Mweka Camp (3,100 m)
day6.distance: Distance: 17 km / 10.5 miles (5 km ascent / 12 km descent)
day6.description:
The big day begins. Wake-up is around 11:30 PM. After hot tea and biscuits, you'll begin your final ascent in darkness and cold. The climb is steep, proceeding "pole pole" (slowly, slowly) on a zigzag trail through scree. This is the most difficult mental and physical test of the trek.

After about 6 hours, you'll reach Stella Point (5,756 m), on the crater rim, just in time to witness the most spectacular sunrise of your life. After a short break, you'll continue along the snow-covered crater rim for another 45 to 60 minutes to reach the true summit: Uhuru Peak (5,895 m), the highest point in Africa!

After photos and celebrations, you'll begin the long descent. You'll return to Barafu for a well-deserved hot meal and short nap, before continuing down to Mweka Camp.

day7.title: Trek Day 7: Mweka Camp (3,100 m) â†’ Mweka Gate (1,640 m) â†’ Hotel
day7.description:
Your last morning on the mountain begins with a hearty breakfast, followed by the traditional tipping ceremony to thank your guides, cooks, and porters.

Then, you'll begin a picturesque and easy descent through the lush rainforest. The trail is well-marked but can be slippery. Upon arrival at Mweka Gate, you'll sign the register and receive your official summit certificate (green certificate for Stella Point, gold for Uhuru Peak).

Our vehicle will be waiting to take you back to your hotel in Moshi or Arusha. The first hot shower in a week will be unforgettable!

departureDay.title: Departure Day: Moshi or Arusha â†’ Airport (JRO)
departureDay.description: Enjoy a leisurely breakfast at your hotel. Depending on your flight schedule, you can relax, buy souvenirs, or explore the town. We'll arrange your return transfer to Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO) for your flight home, or for the continuation of your adventure (safari or Zanzibar).

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.question1: What is the success rate of the Machame Route?
faqs.answer1: The Machame Route has an excellent success rate of approximately 85-90% due to its superior acclimatization profile and longer itinerary.
faqs.question2: How difficult is the Machame Route?
faqs.answer2: The Machame Route is considered moderately challenging. It requires good physical fitness but no technical climbing skills.
faqs.question3: What is the best time to do the Machame Route?
faqs.answer3: The best times are January to March and June to October, when the weather is generally dry and clear.
faqs.question4: What should I pack for the Machame Route?
faqs.answer4: Pack layered clothing, a warm sleeping bag, sturdy hiking boots, and personal essentials. A comprehensive packing list will be provided upon booking.

hero.title: Conquer the Roof of Africa: Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro via the Marangu Route in 5 Days
hero.description: The Marangu Route is the easiest with hut accommodation. It's a direct ascent to the summit with a good acclimatization profile.

day0.title: Day 0: Kilimanjaro Airport Moshi
day0.location: Kilimanjaro from Moshi, Tanzania. Welcome to Tanzania!
day0.description: Upon arrival at Kilimanjaro International Airport, you will be greeted by your guide. Together, you will take the road to Moshi (approximately 60 minutes drive). You are already at your lodge.

day1.title: Day 1: Marangu Gate to Mandara Hut
day1.description: The first day of ascent begins with the transfer to Marangu Gate (1,860m). After registration formalities, the hike engages in the lush rainforest. The path is generally easy and progressive. Optionally, a detour to Maundi Crater is possible. After 3 to 4 hours of walking for about 8km, you reach Mandara Hut (2700m) for the night.

day2.title: Day 2: Mandara Hut to Horombo Hut
day2.description: You leave the rainforest for the vast moorland areas. The path is ascending and offers magnificent views of Mawenzi peak and Kibo dome. The area is characterized by giant lobelias. After 5 to 6 hours of walking for about 12km, you arrive at Horombo Hut (3,700m). This is where you will spend the night and begin to feel the effects of altitude.

day3.title: Day 3: Horombo Hut to Kibo Hut
day3.description: This stage takes you through the barren alpine desert. The landscape becomes rocky, often described as "lunar". The walk takes place on the Kilimanjaro saddle, between Kibo and Mawenzi. After 5 to 6 hours of walking for about 9km, you reach Kibo Hut (4,700m), the base camp. The afternoon is devoted to rest, dinner and meticulous preparation for the summit ascent planned very early in the morning.

day4.title: Day 4: Summit Assault and Descent to Horombo Hut
day4.description: The fourth day is the most decisive. The summit ascent begins very early (between midnight and 2:00 AM) in the darkness, requiring the use of headlamps. The progression is made on steep and thick scree or snow, via numerous switchbacks, to Gilman's Point (5,685m) located on the crater rim. The ascent continues to Uhuru Peak (5,895m), the highest point in Africa. The ascent phase is the most difficult and requires wearing all warm clothing layers. A slow pace, (Pole Pole) (slowly in Swahili), is essential. After immortalizing the moment at the summit, the long descent begins. A stop is planned at Kibo Hut for lunch and a short rest before continuing the descent to Horombo Hut (3,700m).

day5.title: Day 5: Horombo Hut to Marangu Gate
day5.description: The last day is a long but pleasant final descent. You cross the moorland, then the lush forest trail to Marangu Gate (1,860m). At low altitude, the path can be muddy. After 5 to 6 hours of walking, you reach the gate where a vehicle awaits you for the transfer to your hotel in Moshi. You then receive your ascent certificate, marking the completion of your expedition

day6.title: RETURN FLIGHT FROM KILIMANJARO INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT (JRO)
day6.description: After the effort and success of the ascent, Day 6 marks the end of this extraordinary adventure. Following a last well-deserved night of rest, you enjoy a leisurely breakfast. Our team will pick you up from your accommodation and ensure your private transfer to Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO). This is the opportunity to bid farewell to Tanzania, taking with you unforgettable memories of the Roof of Africa. If you don't want the journey to end so soon, don't hesitate to extend your stay for a safari in the Serengeti or a few days of relaxation on the beaches of Zanzibar!

inclusions.items: Dedicated trip manager ||| In-depth preparation documents ||| Pre-climb Zoom consult ||| 2 overnight stays at Lindrin Lodge in Moshi (incl. breakfasts and dinners) ||| In-depth pre-climb safety briefing at Lindrin Lodge ||| Transport to and from trailheads ||| Kilimanjaro National Park entrance fee ||| Qualified, experienced, English-speaking guides ||| Porters ||| Experienced cook ||| All meals on the mountain ||| Snacks and hot drinks ||| Purified drinking water ||| Daily bowl of water for 'washy washy' ||| High-quality, four-season sleeping bag ||| High-quality, four-season sleeping tent ||| Sleeping mat ||| Private Latanzanieaucourdelanature toilet (1 per 8 climbers) ||| Organisation of any rental equipment, if required ||| Medical equipment (incl. pulse oximeter and emergency oxygen) ||| Climb certificate

huts.description: On the Marangu Route, you will stay in comfortable huts located at designated camps. Each hut offers bunk beds with mattresses and is strategically located for optimal acclimatization.

faqs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqs.question1: What is the best time to climb Kilimanjaro via the Marangu Route?
faqs.answer1: The best months to climb Kilimanjaro are January, February, and September through October. These months offer the clearest skies and driest conditions.
faqs.question2: How difficult is the Marangu Route?
faqs.answer2: The Marangu Route is considered the easiest of all Kilimanjaro routes due to its gradual ascent profile and hut accommodation. However, all Kilimanjaro climbs are physically demanding.
faqs.question3: What should I pack for the climb?
faqs.answer3: Essential items include warm clothing, waterproof gear, sturdy hiking boots, a sleeping bag, and personal medications. We provide a detailed packing list after booking.
faqs.question4: What is the success rate for the Marangu Route?
faqs.answer4: The Marangu Route has a success rate of approximately 85%, which is slightly lower than other routes due to its shorter itinerary. Proper acclimatization is key to success.

countryInfo.title: Country info and facts
countryInfo.subtitle: Here's what you need to know logistically to plan a trip to Tanzania, from the best seasons to visa requirements.

airports.title: Airports
airports.content: Most visitors fly into Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO) via Kenya's Jomo Kenyatta International Airport (NBO) in Nairobi or Julius Nyerere International Airport (DAR) in Dar es Salaam. You can also fly into Arusha Airport (ARK), a regional airport that also brings you close to both Mt Kilimanjaro and the game parks of the Northern Circuit.

seasons.title: Seasons
seasons.intro: Tanzania's national parks are open all year round, and each season has its pros and cons.
seasons.longDry: That said, the long dry season (mid June to October) is considered by many as the optimal safari season. This is because the days are a bit cooler, there's little chance of rain, and the dry landscape makes animal spotting that much easier (because the foliage doesn't cover animals, and they're also forced to congregate around water sources).
seasons.shortDry: The short dry season (January to mid March) is also a great time if you like lush landscapes, love birds, and would enjoy being present for the calving season.
seasons.link: Best time for safari in Tanzania
seasons.moreInfo: if you'd like to know more.

visa.title: Visa and Immigration
visa.content: A Tanzanian tourist visa is valid for up to 90 days. It costs US$50 for foreigners, and US$100 for US citizens. But a visa isn't required for nationals from around 50 countries worldwide, including South Africa, Kenya, Hong Kong, Singapore, China, India, Brazil and Turkey.

healthSafety.title: Health and Safety
healthSafety.vaccines: There are no mandatory vaccines for entry into Tanzania.
healthSafety.precautions: Please note that some parts of Tanzania have malaria and tsetse flies (which can cause sleeping sickness). You may wish to take precautions against these. It's also always a good idea to be vaccinated against rabies, especially when travelling anywhere rural.

hero.title: Safari Bivouac 8 Days: The Wild Call of Northern Tanzania
hero.description:
Forget the everyday. This is not just a trip, it's a total immersion. For 8 days, you will live at the rhythm of the heart of Africa, where luxury is measured by the vastness of the sky and the authenticity of the moment.

This safari is tailored for the adventurer within you. By choosing bivouac (camping), you don't just observe nature, you sleep in it. Listen to the distant roar of a lion in the Serengeti, feel the ground vibrate at the passage of Tarangire's elephants, and let yourself be lulled by the night song of the savanna.

day1.title: Day 1 â€“ Arrival
day1.description: Upon arrival at Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO), you will be welcomed and transferred to Arusha to your hotel.

day2.title: Day 2 â€“ Tarangire National Park
day2.description: Today, we head to Tarangire National Park, passing through local Maasai villages along the main road. Here you will see Maasai herding their cattle in green pastures, as well as women searching for firewood and water. Tarangire is an ideal place to see many elephants and Mbuyu trees. There are many wild animals like giraffes, buffalo and leopards.

day3.title: Day 3 â€“ Road to Serengeti National Park
day3.description: After breakfast, we head to Serengeti National Park via the Ngorongoro Conservation Area. We'll stop at the crater rim for a beautiful view of the crater, circling the crater edge to Serengeti Park. Geographically, the Serengeti is divided into two zones: the East-South, which is covered by a vast plain of volcanic ash ejected from the Ngorongoro plateau, hence the name 'Siringet', Maasai word for endless plain. The second zone, in the North-West, consists of forests and small hills.

day4.title: Day 4 â€“ Full Day Safari in Serengeti National Park
day4.description: After breakfast, departure from your camp in a sport utility vehicle. Serengeti National Park is part of the Serengeti ecosystem that is home to the world's largest population of wild animals: over one million wildebeest and nearly half a million zebras follow the rains each year around this ecosystem, from plains to savanna forests, to the Masai Mara and back to the plains.

day5.title: Day 5 â€“ From Ngorongoro Crater to Lake Manyara
day5.description: Descend into the crater. Ngorongoro Crater is one of the world's most beautiful wildlife refuges. It is rather an animal paradise, where some of Africa's last black rhinos are still well protected. A herd of black-backed lions perches in the grass, pink flamingos flock to Lake Magadi and the great tusked elephant is most often seen in the perennial marshes.

day6.title: Day 6 â€“ Lake Manyara National Park
day6.description: This park is known for hosting tree-climbing lions. After breakfast, drive to Lake Manyara National Park passing through the Great Rift Valley, one of the most impressive sites in the world, which stretches from the Dead Sea in Jordan to south of Mozambique. You will traverse Masai country. Lake Manyara Game Reserve owes its name to the plant Euphorbia tirucalii, 'Emanyar' in the Maasai language and 'lady's fingers' in English.

day7.title: Day 7 â€“ From Lake Eyasi to Arusha
day7.description: Around 6:30 AM, after a light breakfast, you will leave the lodge and visit the Hadzabe Bushmen. They are the last hunter-gatherers still present in East Africa, continuing their lives with very few changes since tens of thousands of years ago. You will participate in their morning activities, including forest hiking, hunting and campfire. Other activities can be done during the day: interact with the Hadza, participate in honey collection, search for baobab fruits and enjoy their daily life.

day8.title: Day 8 â€“ Departure from Kilimanjaro
day8.description: Enjoy a leisurely breakfast. Depending on your flight schedule, we will arrange your return transfer to Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO) for your return flight or to continue your adventure (Zanzibar, etc.).

meals.title: Meals
meals.description: Breakfast, unless otherwise stated, is taken at your accommodation. Depending on the program, lunches will be taken in the parks and in the form of picnics to fully enjoy your safari. Please advise in advance if special meal requests (vegetarian, diabetic, etc...) are necessary. Tap water is generally drinkable in large cities but not in rural areas for safety it is better to drink bottled water.

transport.title: Transport
transport.description: The safari is carried out in a 4x4 vehicle, two-seater seats are installed in the direction of travel next to a large opening window. A water tank is reserved for supplies, a large fuel tank allows for long journeys. Possibility to charge camcorders and digital devices on the 12V cigarette lighter socket (bring your cable). In parks and reserves, it is strictly forbidden to stand on the roof of the vehicle.

animals.title: Which Animals to See?
animals.description: Tanzania has thousands of wild animals of all species and you will not be disappointed by the diversity found in the parks (even the smallest or least known): Elephants, giraffes, buffalo, cheetahs, leopards, lions, servals, jackal, Rhinos, Hippos, hyenas, impalas, zebras, monkeys, antelopes, crocodiles, warthogs, Birds... There are many species to see, you won't be disappointed as long as you know how to be patient with nature.

luggage.title: Luggage
luggage.description: On a safari prefer soft luggage to traditional suitcases, bags are much more practical to handle in vehicles especially if you need to retrieve something during a day of observation. Also plan a small backpack in which you will place everything you might need during the day (sunscreen, sunglasses, cameraâ€¦).

whatToPack.title: What to Pack
whatToPack.description:
Think safari: lightweight long-sleeved shirts to protect yourself from the sun and insects, soft pants with side pockets, Pataugas-type shoes for hiking and light sneakers for rest times. Don't forget a fleece as evenings can be cool. A swimsuit will be useful when staying at establishments with a pool. A hat and sunglasses will complete the essential kit for any savanna trip. For all your clothes prefer colors like khaki, dark green, gray, brown. Avoid bright colors and white. Also forget blue because tsetse flies are particularly attracted to this color.

Don't forget a first aid kit containing small bandages (cuts or other), pain relievers (paracetamol or equivalent), sunscreens and insect repellents (the most effective being 5X5).

Also think about your toiletries and a bath towel even if all establishments have them.

You can complete this equipment with a good pair of binoculars like 'Bushnell legend' or equivalent, as this tool is certainly the one you will use most during a safari.

bivouac.title: The Bivouac Experience
bivouac.description:
Taking a trip to Tanzania by opting for bivouac accommodation is a philosophy in itself. Off the beaten path, it is a true adventure favored by adventurers. It is about making a stay that brings you back to fundamentals, leaving everyday comfort behind to focus on nature. What's more exciting than pitching your tent in the middle of the savanna, in the heart of where Africa's greatest animals live.

Certainly the nights can be short as they are conducive to intense wildlife activity. It is not uncommon to hear the growl of lions, to see elephants or herbivores pass a few meters from the bivouac, not to mention hyenas that may prevent you from having a restful sleep but will leave you with a memorable memory.

This kind of trip can be economical but that is not its primary purpose, it is above all to get as close as possible to nature, especially in the parks, to live an unforgettable experience. And obviously it would be unthinkable to take a trip to Tanzania by opting for bivouac accommodation without a minimum of comfort, but all this is handled masterfully:

The tents are two-person, equipped with mattresses and mosquito nets, adapted to the environment, they reflect the spirit of an exceptional safari. Camping sites have all the sanitary facilities and infrastructure allowing for a comfortable stay in the middle of wild nature.

Obviously, during a bivouac trip, in addition to the driver guide, you benefit from a personal chef who ensures you a hearty breakfast, a picnic lunch and an evening meal every day. When you find yourself at the end of the world, in the depths of the savanna and you see what an itinerant chef is capable of preparing under unimaginable conditions, when you taste his dishes, then there is only respect that prevails.

The bivouac is an extraordinary experience, it is for those who want to discover the country with a hint of adventure because you never know what will happen at night! It is certainly the best way to live extraordinary moments in Tanzania, which is aimed first and foremost at those for whom Adventure is a priority. Far from clichÃ©s, to do once in your life, because it is a unique experience from which you emerge enriched and humble.

hero.title: Safari & Zanzibar Beach (10 Days)
hero.description: Combine the thrill of Tanzania's wildlife safari with the paradise beaches of Zanzibar

day1.title: Arusha / First Breath of Africa
day1.description: Upon arrival at Kilimanjaro International Airport, you'll be warmly greeted by your guide who will accompany you to your accommodation in Arusha. Take time to rest and acclimate to the African atmosphere. In the evening, enjoy a welcome dinner where you'll receive a comprehensive briefing about your upcoming safari adventure.

day2.title: Arusha to Tarangire National Park - The Kingdom of Baobabs
day2.description: After breakfast, depart for Tarangire National Park (2-hour drive). Famous for its giant baobabs and large elephant herds, Tarangire offers exceptional wildlife viewing. You'll observe elephants, giraffes, zebras, wildebeests, and if lucky, lions and leopards. Enjoy a picnic lunch within the park, then continue your game drive until late afternoon. Overnight at a lodge near the park.

day3.title: Tarangire to Serengeti National Park - Into the Wild Heart
day3.description: Early morning departure towards the legendary Serengeti National Park (5-6 hour drive through stunning landscapes). Pass through the Ngorongoro Conservation Area with breathtaking views. Arrive in Serengeti for an afternoon game drive across endless plains teeming with wildlife. The Serengeti, meaning 'endless plains' in Maasai, hosts the greatest wildlife spectacle on Earth. Overnight at a lodge or tented camp in Serengeti.

day4.title: Full Day in Serengeti National Park - The Great Migration
day4.description: Dedicate the entire day to exploring Serengeti's wonders. Early morning game drive to spot predators when most active. Return to lodge for breakfast and relaxation before afternoon game drive. Witness the Great Migration (depending on season), observe lions, cheetahs, leopards, elephants, giraffes, and countless other species in their natural habitat. Optional hot air balloon safari available for a unique aerial perspective.

day5.title: Serengeti to Ngorongoro - Journey to the Crater Rim
day5.description: After breakfast, enjoy a final morning game drive in Serengeti before heading to Ngorongoro Conservation Area (3-4 hour drive). Stop at Olduvai Gorge, the 'Cradle of Mankind,' where archaeological discoveries have revealed human evolution secrets. Arrive at your lodge perched on the Ngorongoro Crater rim for spectacular views. Overnight at a crater rim lodge.

day6.title: Ngorongoro Crater - The Garden of Eden
day6.description: Descend 600 meters into the Ngorongoro Crater for a full day of game viewing in this natural wonder, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The crater floor hosts dense wildlife populations including the Big Five (lion, elephant, buffalo, rhino, leopard), flamingos around Lake Magadi, hippos, and diverse birdlife. Enjoy a picnic lunch by the hippo pool. Ascend the crater in late afternoon and transfer to Arusha for overnight stay.

day7.title: Arusha to Zanzibar - Island Paradise Awaits
day7.description: After breakfast, transfer to Arusha Airport for your flight to Zanzibar (approximately 1.5 hours). Upon arrival at Zanzibar Airport, transfer to your beach resort. Spend the afternoon relaxing on pristine white sand beaches, swimming in turquoise waters, or exploring your resort. Enjoy a seafood dinner by the ocean. Overnight at a beach resort in Zanzibar.

day8.title: Safari Blue & Mnemba Dolphin Tour - Marine Magic
day8.description: Embark on the famous Safari Blue excursion - a full day of maritime adventure. Sail on traditional dhow boats to explore the Menai Bay Conservation Area, snorkel in crystal-clear lagoons teeming with tropical fish and coral reefs, visit sandbanks, and enjoy a seafood barbecue on a desert island. Alternatively, take an early morning dolphin tour to Mnemba Atoll for swimming with wild dolphins. Afternoon at leisure on the beach.

day9.title: Stone Town & Spice Farm - Cultural Immersion
day9.description: Discover Stone Town, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with centuries of history. Wander through narrow alleys, visit the former slave market, House of Wonders, Sultan's Palace, and bustling Darajani Market. Afternoon spice farm tour to learn about Zanzibar's spice heritage - smell and taste cloves, vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg, and tropical fruits. Optional visit to Prison Island to see giant tortoises. Return to your beach resort for final evening.

day10.title: Zanzibar Departure - Kwaheri (Farewell)
day10.description: Enjoy a relaxed final morning on the beach. Depending on your flight schedule, you may have time for last-minute souvenir shopping or a final swim. Transfer to Zanzibar Airport for your departure flight, carrying unforgettable memories of Tanzania's wildlife and Zanzibar's tropical paradise.

hero.title: The Daring Escape: Safari & Kilimanjaro Adventure (6 Days)
hero.description: A condensed adventure of a lifetime. This is not a circuit, it's a bold incursion into the heart of Tanzania â€” six days of wildlife intensity followed by the authentic foothills of Kilimanjaro.

day1.title: Day 1: Arusha to Tarangire National Park â€“ Immersion among Giants
day1.description: After an energizing breakfast, depart Arusha for Tarangire National Park. Full day game drives among majestic baobabs; picnic lunch in the park. Tarangire is a water sanctuary for hundreds of elephants, wildebeests and zebras.

day2.title: Day 2: Tarangire to Serengeti National Park â€“ Into the Endless Plains
day2.description: After breakfast, drive to the legendary Serengeti. The drive itself is an experience across open plains (Siringet). Afternoon game drive and an evening game drive when predators are most active.

day3.title: Day 3: Serengeti to Ngorongoro â€“ Dawn of the Hunters
day3.description: Early morning game drive in the Serengeti to track lions, leopards and cheetahs. Brunch, then drive to Ngorongoro with game viewing en route and late arrival at the crater rim.

day4.title: Day 4: Ngorongoro Crater to Arusha Hotel â€“ Eden Restored
day4.description: Descend into the Ngorongoro Crater for approximately six hours of intensive game viewing. Search for the Big Five, picnic at Ngoitoktok spring, then ascend and return to Arusha via a final game drive.

day5.title: Day 5: Materuni Village â€“ Aromas & Secret Waterfalls
day5.description: Cultural immersion at the foot of Kilimanjaro: join a coffee ceremony, learn the process and taste local flavors, then a short hike to a spectacular 90m waterfall with a natural plunge pool.

day6.title: Day 6: Chemka Hot Springs â€“ Oasis Swim & Departure
day6.description: Relax at the clear waters of Chemka Hot Springs before your transfer to the airport according to your flight schedule. Kwaheri!

hero.title: 4 Unforgettable Days in the Heart of Wildlife

day1.title: Day 1 â€“ From Arusha to Tarangire National Park
day1.description: After an early breakfast, depart for Tarangire for a full day of safari with a picnic. Tarangire is renowned for its large elephant herds and baobabs. Dinner and overnight at Lilac camping.

day2.title: Day 2 â€“ From Tarangire to Serengeti National Park
day2.description: After breakfast, depart for the Serengeti. Enjoy a four-hour game drive, followed by an evening safari. Dinner and overnight at Seronera camp.

day3.title: Day 3 â€“ Serengeti to Ngorongoro
day3.description: Morning safari in the Serengeti to observe wildlife then drive to Ngorongoro with a game drive en route. Dinner and overnight at Ngorongoro Simba camping at the crater rim.
